links.title: Topological sorting - Wikipedia
links.description: In computer science, a topological sort or topological ordering of a directed graph is a linear ordering of its vertices such that for every directed edge uv from vertex u to vertex v, u comes before v in the ordering. For instance, the vertices of the graph may represent tasks to be performed, and the edges may represent constraints that one task must be performed before another; in this application, a topological ordering is just a valid sequen...

links.title: Semantic primes - Wikipedia
links.description: Semantic primes or semantic primitives are a set of semantic concepts[1] that are innately understood but cannot be expressed in simpler terms. They represent words or phrases that are learned through practice but cannot be defined concretely. For example, although the meaning of "touching" is readily understood, a dictionary might define "touch" as "to make contact" and "contact" as "touching", providing no information if neither of these words ...

links.title: Sayre's law - Wikipedia
links.description: Sayre's law states, in a formulation quoted by Charles Philip Issawi: "In any dispute the intensity of feeling is inversely proportional to the value of the issues at stake." By way of corollary, it adds: "That is why academic politics are so bitter." Sayre's law is named after Wallace Stanley Sayre (1905–1972), U.S. political scientist and professor at Columbia University.

challenging cases. We study this issue within natural language inference (NLI),

that statistical NLI models may adopt three fallible syntactic heuristics: the

unsupervised and reinforcement learning. The starting point is that the basic

links.description: Microsoft loves Linux so much that its latest operating system is based on Linux. Azure Sphere OS is designed to run on embedded devices and IoT.

links.title: Neural Decipherment via Minimum-Cost Flow: from Ugaritic to Linear B
links.description:
In this paper we propose a novel neural approach for automatic decipherment
of lost languages. To compensate for the lack of strong supervision signal, our
model design is informed by patterns in language change documented in
historical linguistics. The model utilizes an expressive sequence-to-sequence
model to capture character-level correspondences between cognates. To
effectively train the model in an unsupervised manner, we innovate the train...
links.original_title: Neural Decipherment via Minimum-Cost Flow: from Ugaritic to Linear B

links.title: (Can’t) Picture This 2: An Analysis of WeChat's Realtime Image Filtering in Chats - The Citizen Lab
links.description: In this work, we study how Tencent implements image filtering on WeChat. We found that Tencent implements realtime, automatic censorship of chat images on WeChat based on what text is in an image and based on an image’s visual similarity to those on a blacklist. Tencent facilitates this realtime filtering by maintaining a hash index of MD5 hashes of sensitive image files.
links.original_title: An Analysis of WeChat’s Realtime Image Filtering in Chats

links.title: EU Members Approve Upload Filters for "Terrorist Content" - TorrentFreak
links.description: The EU is not only cracking down on copyright-infringing content, there's a strong focus on terrorist material too. The EU Commision recently proposed new regulations that would require hosting platforms to remove terrorist content within one hour, or face consequences. This week member states gave the plan a green light, which goes well beyond Article 13.

links.title: Memory hole - Wikipedia
links.description: A memory hole is any mechanism for the alteration or disappearance of inconvenient or embarrassing documents, photographs, transcripts or other records, such as from a website or other archive, particularly as part of an attempt to give the impression that something never happened.[1][2] The concept was first popularized by George Orwell's dystopian novel Nineteen Eighty-Four, where the Party's Ministry of Truth systematically re-created all pot...

links.title: Signal Messenger - Wikipedia
links.description: Signal Messenger, LLC, is a software organization that was founded by Moxie Marlinspike and Brian Acton in 2018 to take over the role of the Open Whisper Systems project that Marlinspike founded in 2013. Its main focus is the development of the Signal app and the Signal Protocol.[7] The organization is funded by the non-profit Signal Foundation,[4][8] and all of its products are published as free and open-source software.

links.title: Signal (software) - Wikipedia
links.description: Signal is a cross-platform encrypted messaging service developed by the Signal Foundation and Signal Messenger LLC.  It uses the Internet to send one-to-one and group messages, which can include files, voice notes, images and videos.[13] Its mobile apps can also make one-to-one voice and video calls,[14] and the Android version can optionally function as an SMS app.[15]

links.title: Why Has Language Changed So Much So Fast? ‘Because Internet’
links.description: In her new book, the linguist Gretchen McCulloch breaks down just how life online has rewritten the rules of how we communicate.

links.title: The Intelligence  - Unmoving movement: Venezuela’s bloody stalemate
links.description: The opposition’s momentum has faded; many protesters are too tired to go on. Nicolás Maduro, the illegitimate president, is showing his grip on power with shows of force. Global shipping is in a slump—but a visit to the Port of Rotterdam reveals that the industry itself got the message late. And, assessing whether the internet is as ruinous to language as many assume. links.title: Language in Thought and Action

links.title: Reviews of Because Internet
links.description:
I am extremely honoured that the following people who I admire greatly have said nice words about my book on internet language: 

 “Gretchen McCulloch is the internet’s favorite linguist, and this book is essential reading. Reading her work is like suddenly being able to see the matrix. She explains the hows and the whys of the ways we talk online with the deepest empathy, understanding, and compassion.” —Jonny Sun, author of everyone’s a aliebn ...
